events.description: The Reserve Bank of India held its policy rate at 5.25% following a previous cut.
Trade agreements signed between the US and India earlier in the week.
Budget measures aimed at boosting manufacturing and exports.
A persistent decline in technology stocks on Wall Street overnight.

facts.fact_text: The Sensex fell 386 points, or 0.5%, to 82,928 in Friday morning deals.

evidences.evidence_text: The Sensex fell 386 points, or 0.5%, to 82,928 in Friday morning deals

facts.fact_text: The RBI held its policy rate at 5.25% following a 25 bps cut at the December meeting.

evidences.evidence_text: the RBI held its policy rate at 5.25% following a 25 bps cut at the December meeting

facts.fact_text: The RBI upwardly revised its GDP growth forecast to 7.4% from 7.3% for FY2025–26.

evidences.evidence_text: the RBI’s upward revision of its GDP growth forecast to 7.4% from 7.3% for FY2025–26

facts.fact_text: Technology stocks fell 2.1%, with TCS down 2.4% and Tech Mahindra down 2.1%.

evidences.evidence_text: technology stocks, which fell 2.1% amid the global rout, weighed down by TCS (-2.4%) and Tech Mahindra (-2.1%)

claims.claim_text: The broader Indian market tracked a downbeat session on Wall Street due to a tech rout.

evidences.evidence_text: The broader market tracked a downbeat session on Wall Street overnight amid a persistent tech rout.

claims.claim_text: US-India trade deals and budget measures helped limit the market's losses.

evidences.evidence_text: US–India trade deals earlier this week and the government’s budget measures to boost manufacturing and exports helped cap losses.

claims.claim_text: The RBI's GDP growth forecast revision prevented the stock market from falling further.

evidences.evidence_text: the RBI’s upward revision of its GDP growth forecast to 7.4% from 7.3% for FY2025–26 prevented deeper declines.

evidence.evidence_text: the RBI held its policy rate at 5.25% following a 25 bps cut at the December meeting.
The broader market tracked a downbeat session on Wall Street overnight amid a persistent tech rout.
the RBI’s upward revision of its GDP growth forecast to 7.4% from 7.3% for FY2025–26
government’s budget measures to boost manufacturing and exports helped cap losses.
